title: Geography: Regions and Landforms

vocab.definition: An area that has similar characteristics or features
A natural feature of Earth's surface like mountains, valleys, or plains
The usual weather patterns in an area over a long time
Materials from nature that people use, like water, oil, or trees
A map that shows natural features like mountains and rivers
Flat land that is generally good for farming
A low area of land between hills or mountains
High, flat land with steep sides
The wearing away of rock and soil by water, wind, or ice
When sediment is dropped in a new place by water, wind, or ice
A landform at a river's mouth made by deposited sediment
Bringing water to land to help grow crops
A barrier built across a river to hold back water
A house built on posts to avoid floods or wet ground
One of Earth's large landmasses such as Africa or Asia
Land surrounded by water on three sides
A narrow strip of land connecting two larger land areas
A group or chain of islands
A deep, narrow valley with steep sides
The place where land meets the ocean or sea
How high the land is above sea level
Lines on a map that run east-west and tell how far north or south a place is
Lines on a map that run north-south and tell how far east or west a place is
A tool on a map that shows how distances on the map compare to real distances
A symbol on a map that shows directions (N, S, E, W)

teachingNotes: Study major regions of your state and country. Compare different landforms and how they affect where people live and work. Use physical maps to identify geographical features.

sample.question: What makes one region different from another?
Name a landform found in your state.

truefalse.question: Mountains, valleys, and plains are all landforms.
Climate and weather are exactly the same.
Physical maps show rivers and mountains.
All regions have the same climate.
People often live near water for resources and travel.
Plateaus are low, flat areas at sea level.
Geography can affect what jobs people do.
